Zipkin server nested into my own monitoring application

It is possible, yes, but unsupported.

On 19 Dec 2017 7:08 pm, "jidianxiake" <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Zipkin server nested into my own monitoring application
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/1853#issuecomment-352716599>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAD61zwBs7EpEFssBDActRoGFnrEQJJ1ks5tB5lAgaJpZM4RGVx->
> .
>
If I do not put together, I will open a separate server, increasing costs
If I do that, I need to change my project into a springboot project

Zipkin is typically used for distributed applications, meaning more than
one process across one or more hosts. It uses a single listen port, so can
share the same host as other processes. Co-locating in one JVM is only
possible with spring boot, unless you write a even more custom app.

People usually encounter issues when they try to make custom servers which
increases the burden on this project which is why it isnt supported. If you
create a custom server you will need to bear the burden of supporting it.
That support burden may cost you more in salary than the resources to start
a couple hundred megabyte JVM.

Hope this info helps guide your decision and good luck.

only way to diagnose this type of issue is to see the raw trace sent.

If your storage is v2 (elasticsearch or cassandra3), use
/api/v2/trace/trace_id. Otherwise, use /api/v1/trace/trace_id?raw

please use a paste link or wrap in ``` to format it

I guess this is awaiting small feedback fixies

FYI: I know folks have been used to me merging and releasing things, which is awesome because I have time to do it, and I prefer volunteers having time for code, docs and helping others.
Heads up: I will be out from 24 Dec back 3 Jan, so someone else will need to merge things in in that span (hehe) or wait till I'm back.

PS rod mentioned this for content https://vimeo.com/247562710

beyond selfish aims of maintaining things, seems atomist could also be a way to help instrument libraries. I didn't think of this angle.

Happy to see how we could help. Distributed library updates are definitely doable; we've examples in both Maven and `package.json`.

- Are we talking about updating `npm` stuff, Java stuff, other? Any sample PRs we could look at to see what we're talking about?
- Which orgs?

sure. here are some examples. some have inherent workflow so not sure if appropriate or not

### automatically update to latest finagle version
* Finagle updates once a month, but the day might change. Update and immediately cut a release
  * nag issue placeholder https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-finagle/issues/38
  * version bump before release tag https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-finagle/commit/221a74bc7f7e8f5f045e09afcddd65df571f1824

### update spring-cloud-sleuth
* once a "notable" release is done to our core library, put it in spring-cloud-sleuth. deployment decoupled as out of our org, usually 2 branches to do
  * https://github.com/spring-cloud/spring-cloud-sleuth/commit/92e434e26129bef00215cd20253a58b32c8ee12d

### update extension to our docker image
* update extension library with latest zipkin, on green build make a release-0.8.5 tag to kick automation
  * thing to do to update versions: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-aws/commit/107d9df6cadcd68c20547e4bba9b3543522c1f62
* once that's done, it is synced to bintray, so we can update and cut a docker image via 0.8.5 tag
  * thing to do to update versions: https://github.com/openzipkin/docker-zipkin-aws/commit/91198770444766a848e7a8900de1702ab1b658e3

All these look doable. 

- I assume cutting a release means a tag and updating release notes?
- Not sure I fully understand the POM changes here, but certainly editing the POM is a core capability
- Editing docker files is also relatively easy

Another angle is we have a number of example projects to show how to configure zipkin. While some are starting anew, many are copy-pasting things out of these into existing apps. Some sort of means to inject zipkin could be great for support.

https://github.com/openzipkin/brave-webmvc-example
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-php-example
https://github.com/openzipkin/brave-webmvc-example
(there are many others)

@adriancole I have add a whitelist by myself. which still consume lot of space. I plan to develop a customed TokenizingAnalyzer.

> It is possible we could allow a config to whitelist keys to index (like http.path)

@adriancole, a whitelist sounds like a good idea to start with.

beyond that: the only reason we're using `CONTAINS` here is because SASI on collections types are not supported. see https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CASSANDRA-11182

i'm thinking the right way to move forward would be to denormalise the annotations like…
```
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS zipkin2.span_by_annotation_query (
    trace_id            text, // when strictTraceId=false, only contains right-most 16 chars
    ts_uuid             timeuuid,
    id                  text,
    trace_id_high       text, // when strictTraceId=false, contains left-most 16 chars if present
    annotation_query    text, 
    PRIMARY KEY         (trace_id, ts_uuid, id, annotation_query)
);

CREATE CUSTOM INDEX IF NOT EXISTS ON zipkin2.span_by_annotation_query (annotation_query) USING 'org.apache.cassandra.index.sasi.SASIIndex'
   WITH OPTIONS = {'mode': 'PREFIX'};
```
Each annotation would be written to `annotation_query`, instead of the `░` joined string.

And the look-up would then mean in `SelectTraceIdsFromSpan`…

 - the statement would instead be prepared with `QueryBuilder.like("annotation_query", bindMarker("annotation_query"))`
 - and the statement called with  just `annotationKey` instead of `"%░" + annotationKey + "░%"`.

This would allow removing the `span.annotation_query` column and its `CONTAINS` SASI.

A custom TokenizingAnalyzer is another approach, and would be very cool to see.

If you want to configure jvm, you can run this command(just an example):
```
$ sudo STORAGE_TYPE=mysql MYSQL_USER=root MYSQL_PASS=123456 nohup java -Xms2g -Xmx2g -jar zipkin.jar &
```

dupes are removed when both key and value match. duped key with different values will continue to be reported as it might signal important info and we don't know which one is correct if not both.

Given different platforms and instrumenting libraries I don't think you can say those annotation timings always properly map latency.

I do see the value of seeing deltas between timings so we could make it more generic and add a delta column to the annotations table which go beyond just CS/SR/SS/CR annotations.

@igorwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwww I think you are also interested in sort behavior. There is some background here.. probably worthwhile to see how other timeseries projects who support cassandra backend do multiple index sorting as cassandra is the more popular backend and mysql doesn't scale (as it is currently designed)

My client is using Spring Cloud discovery to register Zipkin instances in Zookeeper.
Do you expect span's `name` be the same as `http.template` in the most cases? Or they semantically different?

I'm not opposed to this, but 1) i'm not sure about the name and 2) i don't know if it's necessary

I'm not sure about the name, because I don't know if a template (assuming we're talking [URI templates](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6570) here) is sufficient. Here's an example:

We have this exact problem with our [swagger](https://swagger.io/) RPC endpoints. Using the petstore [example](http://petstore.swagger.io/), `GET /pet/{petId}` will show up as `/pet/1234` in the `http.uri`. So 1) it is difficult to know that that corresponds to the `/pet/{petId}` path template, and 2) it is impossible to know that it corresponds to the GET version of that vs the DELETE or POST versions.

We solve the second problem by making the span `name` equal to the method and the path in [pyramid_zipkin](https://github.com/Yelp/pyramid_zipkin/blob/master/pyramid_zipkin/tween.py#L64). However, this doesn't solve the path parameter problem (the uri template).

The Correct Way to solve this would be to use any identifier guaranteed to uniquely identify the endpoint, which in the swagger case is [operationId](https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/master/versions/3.0.1.md#operation-object). I think that this should just be set as the span `name` as I think @SergeyKanzhelev is alluding to. This is why I'm saying that it is probably not necessary.

> The Correct Way to solve this would be to use any identifier guaranteed to uniquely identify the endpoint

Effectively I think that is what `http.template` is in this proposal. Making the parameterized URI the _de facto_ identifier across many frameworks makes your traces/metrics look somewhat uniform across the org (i.e. those services using Swagger and those that are not).

>
> The Correct Way to solve this would be to use any identifier guaranteed to
> uniquely identify the endpoint
>
> Effectively I think that is what http.template is in this proposal.
>
right, probably the fact that a template is present or not could be
distracting. For example, "post /foo" as long as it has no variables is
also fine (ex not a template). Maybe the name template is not great. The
goal indeed is to uniquely identify the endpoint.. there is definitely a
secondary goal of it being human readable. For example, a hashed identifier
wouldn't be great as some will optionally choose to use this as a span name
or a human readable label.

>
> Do you expect span's name be the same as http.template in the most cases?
> Or they semantically different?
>
What's currently known as http.template is a better span name for most
people than something like "get". However, think of the redirect case, it
would be "REDIRECT" or something else it would have infinite cardinality.
The other issue is that a span can fail before it can know its endpoint.
This is behind the heuristic of a tentative name even if you are planning
to use template at response time (if you get a response).

Reason I hesitated about saying it is semantically the span name is because
the name is up to users to decide. This could be a decent choice, but could
be added as a tag regardless.

>
> I'm not sure about the name, because I don't know if a template (assuming
> we're talking URI templates <https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6570> here)
> is sufficient. Here's an example:
>
> We have this exact problem with our swagger <https://swagger.io/> RPC
> endpoints. Using the petstore example <http://petstore.swagger.io/>, GET
> /pet/{petId} will show up as /pet/1234 in the http.uri. So 1) it is
> difficult to know that that corresponds to the /pet/{petId} path
> template, and 2) it is impossible to know that it corresponds to the GET
> version of that vs the DELETE or POST versions.
>
^^ is a tricky problem, and something to deal with in implementation. In
brave, we are thinking about using both the request and response to derive
the template, which means you can see what the method is. When you can't
derive a template, you don't produce the tag. Ex. if the framework can't
tell you, then probably better to not add a tag than add one with infinite
cardinality.

On URI templates, for better or worse we already know that deviations are
used, so probably not best to promise URI template formatting, rather focus
on the limited cardinality aspect.
Whether or not DELETE or POST is in the template is up to us to decide.
Http methods are fixed cardinality, and since a primary consumer of this is
metrics, it sort of depends on if the system supports multiple lookup keys
or not. One thing that could be easier is this.. It is often easier to
strip a method than assume it is always there. We could say that the
template or whatever we call it tag does not include the method. In fact
this is probably easier for all frameworks I can think of.. Would that
help?

Just want to make a note that Spring's `HandlerMapping.BEST_MATCHING_PATTERN_ATTRIBUTE` does not normalize away extraneous slashes.
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/1876 will fix this (still needs a bit of work to make the schema install not add the indexes vs just not use them)

With `indexing=false` do you still want the writes to be getting amplified (which will happen unless the SASI are dropped via `cql`)?

@adriancole that would be hiding the annotations query input, right? should be quite straight forward to change in zipkin-ui.

Have you considered a slightly more optimized rendering technique?  I haven't profiled things myself but the places I'd start poking around are:
1. Mustache templates; are they slow to compile/render at that scale?
2. Lazy render; only add to the DOM what is visible and potentially start with things collapsed after a certain threshold.

Our use case, btw, is that we have a fairly involved data gathering/generation system that sometimes has to do a deep dive through various web services to get all of it's data.  We try to identify repeated requests and consolidate them into bulk requests (in code, not zipkin) to alleviate this issue but we still have it on occasion.

One of our biggest improvements in this area was to break up traces so that the typical "large traces" now link to "child traces" so that you can see at the high level how long things took or navigate off to another trace to see detail for a particular section.
Tip: we were able to scale Jaeger UI to 50k spans by using a viewport technique.
@adriancole This is awesome! It'd have probably taken me a week to find all the places I needed to change :)

Should we add something like this, knowing this? the configuration would be
a bit spaghetti and the ask while valid is a little late considering where
we are today.

Thoughts?

Hello there! Happy to see this moving :smile: 

Is the scope of this fixed to HTTP-related Spans? I can totally see a similar tag/mechanism working to gather metrics on JDBC call spans and anything else that looks like it (Cassandra driver, etc). This happens to be a pretty common topic when people are starting to instrument their apps.. they usually end up with either too little granularity or a crazy explosion of metrics unless some better naming is manually applied. Anything we can do to provide better default names out of the box is a instant win to all users!

PS: Play Framework does a really nice job at exposing the route templates [through tags](https://github.com/playframework/playframework/blob/master/framework/src/play/src/main/scala/play/core/routing/GeneratedRouter.scala#L234-L238), that might be worth adding in the description.

Thanks for the tips, folks. I don't think many have mentioned concrete
ways to improve UI performance. Lucky for us though
@igorwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwww has been active in related performance work
and who knows... might be able to carry this forward.

The most concrete way to improve the UI is available, capable hands.
We don't have fulltime UI staff, so appreciate volunteers who offer
advice or take time to fix things. Thank you.

added elasticsearch implementation. there are a few areas we need some unit tests, and generally some docs. We also need to have the UI conditional on the searchEnabled property

@adriancole following is current disk space usage

Index Size/ Data Size ratio is 0.15. I remeber old ratio is 60, even bigger. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16414369/34904936-5eefbcb0-f88a-11e7-86ec-b8f2c01a041e.png)

Since we save a lot of spans every day. query latency is very high with annotation_query index.  most of the time, we just got a timeout error. I have move column 'annotation_query' to table 'trace_by_service_span' . that gives us a reasonable response time.

ex:

an query like 
http://*/zipkin/?serviceName=all&spanName=all&startTs=1515834112059&endTs=1515837712059&minDuration=&limit=10&annotationQuery=error&sortOrder=duration-desc

query with annotation_index on table span will show timeout error at last.

query with annotation_index on table trace_by_service_span has a latency lower than 5 seconds, which is acceptable.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16414369/34905037-c8ab9484-f88b-11e7-9c8f-cc5e1707cde9.png)

It looks like you're trying to use a Spring Cloud Sleuth Stream Server. Zipkin has [native support for RabbitMQ as a collector](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/tree/master/zipkin-collector/rabbitmq) now, so you can use it with the standard Zipkin server instead of making a custom one. It may be easier to diagnose this kind of issue via chat: feel free to join us on [Zipkin's Gitter](https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin). That being said, it looks like there's connection trouble with your RabbitMQ.
